title: Bartizan
listingDescription: At the end of the South Rim Trail, visitors reach the Bartizan, elevation 9,725ft, along the park's southern boundary.
bodyText:
At the end of the South Rim Trail, visitors reach the Bartizan, elevation 9,725ft, along the park's southern boundary. From the Bartizan hikers can see two spectacular arches and at the right time of year a waterfall is visible.

Visitors should use extreme caution on the South Rim Trail and at Spectra Point as many area feature steep drop-off just off the trail. There are no railings at the Bartizan, visitors should remain back from the edge as the ground can be unstable. Dogs are not permitted on the South Rim Trail.

NOTE: The final portion of the South Rim Trail is currently being reconstructed, this portion will not be open until Summer 2021.
audioDescription: At the top of a small rise, this red dirt view point is surrounded in nearly every direction are red, pink, and orange rock formations.

title: Cedar Breaks Information Center
listingDescription: Due to construction of the park's new Visitor Contact Station during the 2021 & 2022 seasons, the Point Supreme Overlook will be completely blocked from visitor access. The park has moved visitor services to other areas of the park to address visitor needs during these seasons.

images.altText: A one story log building with a green roof, cars are parked in front.
images.title: Cedar Breaks Information Center
images.caption: Cedar Breaks Information Center for the 2021-2024 seasons.

bodyText:
Due to construction of the park's new Visitor Contact Station during the 2021-2024 seasons, the Point Supreme Overlook will be completely blocked from visitor access. The park has moved visitor services to other areas of the park to address visitor needs during these seasons. Rangers are staffing the Information Center which is located at the southern end of the park. The Information Center is on the east side of Rim Road. At this Information Center, visitors can speak with a ranger, pay their entrance fee, purchase an interagency park pass, pick up a junior ranger program, visit the park store, and get their passport stamped. 


Park Store

The park store is in the same building as the Information Center (southeast of Point Supreme) and will be open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Ranger Programs

Park rangers will be offering public programs daily. For specific information, including starting locations and time, on daily programming visit the calendar page or stop by the information center or booth in the park. Programs will be posted online one month in advance.

Restrooms

The vault toilets at the Picnic Area will be open for visitor use. The restrooms at Point Supreme will be closed for the duration of the 2021-2024 seasons. Portable toilets will be added to the Information Center (southeast of Point Supreme) and North View Overlook in mid-June. Please plan ahead when traveling to the park.
NOTE: Campground restrooms are for registered campers only.
audioDescription: A one story log cabin stands against trees with a modestly sized paved parking lot out front.
passportStampLocationDescription: The park's passport stamp is located in the Park Store inside the Information Center. The park store is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily.

title: Chessmen Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Overlooking Chessmen Ridge, this overlook is centrally located on the rim overlooking the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater.

images.altText: Three people look over railings to rock formations in the distance.
images.title: Chessmen Ridge Overlook
images.caption: Chessman Ridge Overlook

bodyText:
Overlooking Chessmen Ridge, this overlook is centrally located on the rim overlooking the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater. It is the highest elevation overlook in the park at 10,461ft and offers stunning views of the ridge and surrounding formations. The overlook features one of the larger parking lots and can be used to access a bristlecone pine grove and the Alpine Pond Loop Trail by the Chessmen Ridge Spur Trail beginning at the overlook parking lot.

The area is open year-round, but access does vary throughout the year depending upon weather. Once the park road is closed to vehicle access (normally in November each year), the overlook is only accessible by snowshoe, cross-country skies, or snowmobiles.
audioDescription: The large circular parking lot for this overlook is connected to the main park road via a short connector road. At the parking lot, a paved path to the left leads up a small hill to the overlook and to the right the paved path leads to a dirt trail into the woods where it connects with other trails. The overlook is a small circular paved area surrounded by low stone walls and overlooking pink, red, and orange rock formations below.

title: Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
listingDescription: The Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area preserves the natural, historical, and cultural heritage legacies and contributions of Mormon settlement in the West. The heritage area accomplishes this through community-led efforts to connect with the past by telling the Mormon pioneer story.

images.credit: Photo Courtesy of the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
images.altText: Two cowboys on horseback silhouetted against sunset.
images.title: Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
images.caption: Visit the “Old West” - Come to the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area

bodyText:
Designated by Congress in 2006, this National Heritage Area is managed by the Utah Heritage Highway Alliance. The landscape along Highways 12, 24, and 89, now known as the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area, was originally occupied by the Paiute, Ute, and San Pitch Native American tribes. Today, the MPNHA spreads across six counties in Utah and stretches from Central Utah to the southern edge of the state. It preserves the story of the first Mormon pioneers in the area who settled there in 1849. The settlers were a “handpicked group of men, women, and children originally hailing from New England, England and Scandinavia,” and traces their settlement patterns across the United States into Utah.

This National Historic Area provides many opportunities to explore Mormon Pioneer heritage with five heritage districts:  

  • Little Denmark – Visit Little Denmark for its rich Scandinavian pioneer influence and stories of immigration. They even have an annual Scandinavian Heritage Festival in Ephraim.  

  • Sevier Valley – A rich landscape where farmers and ranchers followed the ancient Native American tradition of living off the land. Visit the Sevier Valley district for Big Rock Candy Mountain or Lemonade Springs.  

  • Headwaters – This district is known for its rich mining history and network of rivers and tributaries. Visit this area to find “abandoned mines and tales of lost gold.”  

  • Under the Rim – This district is frequented by Hollywood producers looking for a wild west feel. It is named after the red rock rims of the High Plateau of Utah. 

  • Boulder Loop – Visit the Boulder Loop district for an awe-inspiring heritage byway showcasing cowboy and pioneer trails, Bryce Canyon and Capitol Reef National Parks and the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument. 

Each district boasts a unique history while remaining connected to the larger focus of Mormon Pioneer heritage. Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area is beloved among many communities in Utah and is sure to make an impact on all who visit!  

Historic Sites and Points of Interest: 

  • Fairview Museum of History and Art
  • Manti Temple - 1888
  • Casino Star Theatre
  • Moroni Opera House - 1890
  • Big Rock Candy Mountain
  • Scandinavian Heritage Festival
  • Escalante Pioneer Heritage Center
  • Kimberly - Ghost Town Natural History/Pioneer Museum
  • Circleville M. Parker (Butch Cassidy Cabin) - 1878
  • Kanab - Parry Lodge, Home to the Movie Stars Little Hollywood Walk of Fame

Notable People:  

  • Butch Cassidy
  • Brigham Young
  • Chief Sanpitch
  • Chief Blackhawk
  • The Daughters of the Utah Pioneers (past, present, and future
audioDescription: This heritage area landscape is distinguished by its rugged terrain, diverse rock features and geology, and unique small communities connected along Highway 89. There is a variety of geological and geographical features, such as rocky terrain, red cliffs, forests, and rivers.The Colorado River (including its tributaries), wind, and rain have physically shaped this region, which helped to create its canyons, arches, and gullies. Also of interest are Native American sites and cliff drawings, highlighting the years before settlement of Mormon Pioneers.

quickFacts.value: The Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area (MPNHA) preserves the natural, historical, and cultural heritage legacies and contributions of Mormon settlement in the West. The heritage area accomplishes this through community-led efforts to connect with the past by telling the Mormon pioneer story. By increasing tourism along Utah’s Highways 12, 24, and 89, The MPNHA revitalizes communities through economic development initiatives and drives tourism to small communities along these routes.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: North View Overlook
listingDescription: The northern-most scenic overlook at the national monument, North View is located just inside the north entrance along Highway 143.

images.altText: A short stone wall stands on the rim of a large geologic amphitheater extending into the distance.
images.title: North View Overlook
images.caption: North View Overlook

bodyText:
The northern-most scenic overlook at the national monument, North View is located just inside the north entrance along Highway 143. The overlook features a large parking lot and interpretive waysides. The overlook is accessible by private vehicles.

The area is open year-round, but access does vary throughout the year depending upon weather. Utah Department of Transportation clears Highway 143 during daylight hours in the winter season, though the overlook parking lot is not cleared. During the winter, the overlook can be accessed by snowshoes or cross-country skies.
audioDescription: A large semi-circular parking lot is located just off the road. On the western edge of this parking lot a wide gravel and paved area narrows into a single path leading out to the overlook. At the overlook a circular paved area surrounded by low stone walls overlooks pink, red, and orange rock formations below.

title: Point Supreme Overlook
listingDescription: Since its establishment in 1933, Point Supreme Overlook has served as the primary scenic viewpoint for visitors to the rim of the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater.

images.altText: A paved path extends away from the camera leading to an overlook.
images.title: Point Supreme Overlook
images.caption: The Point Supreme Overlook

bodyText:
Since its establishment in 1933, Point Supreme Overlook has served as the primary scenic viewpoint for visitors to the rim of the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater. From this point, at 10,350ft, visitors can see the incredible formations created by the weathering and erosion over thousands of years. As the primary overlook, this point offers several visitor services including a restroom, information booth, park store, and public programming. These services are available during the summer season, traditionally between June and September each year.

The overlook is accessible by private vehicles from a small parking lot. The area is always open, but access does vary throughout the year depending upon weather. Once the park road is closed to vehicle access (normally in November each year), the overlook is only accessible by snowshoe, cross-country skies, or snowmobiles.
audioDescription: Beginning at the small parking lot, a paved walkway extends to the west. There are two small buildings, a restroom and fee booth, on the left side of this walkway. Continuing along the pathed path, a trail splits to the right. Beyond this intersection a small log cabin is located on the right side of the path. The path ends at a wide paved area surrounded by log railings and overlooking pink, red, and orange rock formations below.

title: Ramparts
listingDescription: At the 2-mile point along the South Rim Trail, hikers reach the Ramparts, elevation 9,952ft.

images.altText: A wooden sign in the foreground reads Ramparts Overlook, rock formations are behind in the distance.
images.title: Ramparts
images.caption: Ramparts is currently the end of the South Rim Trail.

bodyText:
At the 2-mile point along the South Rim Trail, hikers reach the Ramparts, elevation 9,952ft. From the Ramparts hikers can experience the southern side of the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater from a unique and rewarding perspective. Visitors should use extreme caution on the South Rim Trail and at Ramparts as many areas feature steep drop-off just off the trail.

There are no railings at the Ramparts, visitors should remain back from the edge as the ground can be unstable. Dogs are not permitted on the South Rim Trail.
audioDescription: At the top of a small rise, this red dirt view point is surrounded in nearly every direction are red, pink, and orange rock formations.

title: Spectra Point

images.altText: A black-tube railing surrounds a semi-level gravel area overlooking a massive rock formation.
images.title: Spectra Point
images.caption: Spectra Point is located at the one-mile point along the South Rim Trail.

bodyText:
At the 1-mile point along the South Rim Trail, a short spur trail connects to this incredible viewpoint. From Spectra Point, elevation 10,285ft, hikers can see arches, windows, and hoodoos within the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater. At the intersection of the South Rim Trail and the Spectra Point Spur Trail is a large grove of bristlecone pines.

Visitors should use extreme caution on the South Rim Trail and at Spectra Point as many areas feature steep drop-off just off the trail. Visitors to Spectra Point should remain behind the railing provided. Dogs are not permitted on the South Rim Trail.
audioDescription: A semi-level white gravel landing surrounded by a black railing. Beyond the railing in nearly every direction are red, pink, and orange rock formations.

title: Sunset View Overlook
listingDescription: This small overlook is just a mile north of the Point Supreme Overlook, this area can be accessed by the Sunset Trail or a small roadside parking area.

images.altText: The sunsets silhouetting two people standing at a railing looking toward the sun.
images.title: Sunset View Overlook
images.caption: Sunset View Overlook

bodyText:
This small overlook is just a mile north of the Point Supreme Overlook, this area can be accessed by the Sunset Trail or a small roadside parking area. The overlook faces directly west and is a favorite of plein-air artists. The Civilian Conservation Corps camp was located near this overlook during the 1930s when they constructed many of the visitor facilities and amenities in the park today.

The area is open year-round, but access does vary throughout the year depending upon weather. Once the park road is closed to vehicle access (normally in November each year), the overlook is only accessible by snowshoe, cross-country skies, or snowmobiles.
audioDescription: Beginning at the very small parking area, a narrow paved path extends to the west. At the end of the short path, is a paved circular area surrounded by railings and overlooking pink, red, and orange rock formations below.
